In the legal systems of ORG the concept of “ confiscation ” generally refers to a measure the effect of which is permanent deprivation of property by way of transfer of that property to the ORG . CARDINAL countries ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) provide for confiscation orders regardless of conviction . This type of confiscation order generally covers property that has been acquired though unlawful activities . As long as the origin can not be justified , confiscation of such property may be imposed . Criminal liability of the offender is not relevant for the purposes of the confiscation order . For example , in GPE a court may order the confiscation of the proceeds of the crime despite the fact that the proceedings have been discontinued , as long as it can be established that a wrongful act has indeed been committed .

CARDINAL . Five States ( GPE , GPE , GPE , the GPE and GPE ) in principle require conviction as a prerequisite for confiscation whilst allowing for some exceptions to the general rule . In GPE , if it is established or there are reasonable grounds to believe that the suspect committed the offence , confiscation of property acquired through that offence is permitted , even if the suspect is not ultimately convicted because of his or her death . GPE and GPE allow confiscation of property which constitutes material evidence in limited circumstances . In the GPE , as a rule , a confiscation order will not be available upon the death of the accused . However , confiscation of the property that has already been seized can be imposed if it is plausible that the deceased had indeed committed an economic crime .
